03.orig_text: At 0800 UTC, the Bank of Canada, the Bank of England, the European Central Bank (ECB), the United States Federal Reserve, the Bank of Japan, and the Swiss National Bank jointly announced that they would be working together to provide reciprocal credit arrangements to institutions facing a financial crush from the U.S. dollar.
03.text: At 0800 UTC, the Bank of Canada, the Bank of England, the European Central Bank (ECB), the United States Federal Reserve, the Bank of Japan, and the Swiss National Bank jointly announced that they would be working together to provide reciprocal credit arrangements to institutions facing a financial crush from the U.S. dollar.

04.orig_text: The credit arrangements, also known as ``swap lines``, will be used to help short-term funding of smaller loan groups.
04.text: The credit arrangements, also known as ``swap lines``, will be used to help short-term funding of smaller loan groups.

05.orig_text: Totaling US$180 billion, the Federal Reserve arranged to increase existing swap lines with the European Central Bank from US$55 billion to US$110 billion, and with the Swiss National Bank from US$12 billion to US$27 billion.
05.text: Totaling US$180 billion, the Federal Reserve arranged to increase existing swap lines with the European Central Bank from US$55 billion to US$110 billion, and with the Swiss National Bank from US$12 billion to US$27 billion.

06.orig_text: Additionally, it opened new swap lines with the Bank of Japan for up to US$60 billion, up to US$40 billion with the Bank of England, and up to US$10 billion with the Bank of Canada.
06.text: Additionally, it opened new swap lines with the Bank of Japan for up to US$60 billion, up to US$40 billion with the Bank of England, and up to US$10 billion with the Bank of Canada.

07.orig_text: These swap lines will be available until January 30, 2009.
07.text: These swap lines will be available until January 30, 2009.

08.orig_text: In its press release, the Federal Reserve stated, ``These measures, together with other actions taken in the last few days by individual central banks, are designed to improve the liquidity conditions in global financial markets.
08.text: In its press release, the Federal Reserve stated, ``These measures, together with other actions taken in the last few days by individual central banks, are designed to improve the liquidity conditions in global financial markets.

02.orig_text: United States automobile manufacturing firm General Motors filed for bankruptcy and Chapter 11 protection from its creditors at 12:00 UTC Monday, in a Manhattan, New York federal bankruptcy court.
02.text: United States automobile manufacturing firm General Motors filed for bankruptcy and Chapter 11 protection from its creditors at 12:00 UTC Monday, in a Manhattan, New York federal bankruptcy court.

03.orig_text: This was the largest bankruptcy filing for a U.S. manufacturing company, and with declared assets of $82.29 billion and a debt of $172.81 billion, and the fourth largest bankruptcy filing in recent U.S. history -- after the bankruptcies of Lehman Brothers ($691.06 billion), Washington Mutual ($327.91 billion), and WorldCom ($103.91 billion).

00.orig_text: Barack Obama presents rescue plan after GM declaration of bankruptcy
00.text: Barack Obama presents rescue plan after GM declaration of bankruptcy

02.orig_text: In a televised speech from the White House at 16:00 UTC today, President of the United States Barack Obama presented a reorganization plan following the 12:00 UTC announcement by General Motors that it had filed for bankruptcy and Chapter 11 protection from its creditors, the largest bankruptcy of a U.S. manufacturing company.
02.text: In a televised speech from the White House at 16:00 UTC today, President of the United States Barack Obama presented a reorganization plan following the 12:00 UTC announcement by General Motors that it had filed for bankruptcy and Chapter 11 protection from its creditors, the largest bankruptcy of a U.S. manufacturing company.

03.orig_text: Describing the problem with the company as one that had been ``decades in the making,`` Obama explained the rationale behind his proposed reorganization plan for General Motors.
03.text: Describing the problem with the company as one that had been ``decades in the making,`` Obama explained the rationale behind his proposed reorganization plan for General Motors.

04.orig_text: He stated that his intent was not to ``perpetuate] the bad business decisions of the past,`` and that loaning General Motors money, when debt was its problem, would have been doing exactly that.
04.text: He stated that his intent was not to ``perpetuate] the bad business decisions of the past,`` and that loaning General Motors money, when debt was its problem, would have been doing exactly that.

05.orig_text: His plan, he stated, was for the United States government, in conjunction with the governments of Canada and Ontario (which he thanked for their roles alongside the government of Germany which he thanked for its role in selling a corporate stake in GM Europe), to become shareholders in General Motors.
05.text: His plan, he stated, was for the United States government, in conjunction with the governments of Canada and Ontario (which he thanked for their roles alongside the government of Germany which he thanked for its role in selling a corporate stake in GM Europe), to become shareholders in General Motors.

06.orig_text: The United States government would hold a 60% stake.
06.text: The United States government would hold a 60% stake.

07.orig_text: The government will give GM a capital infusion of US$30 billion in addition to the funds it has already received.
07.text: The government will give GM a capital infusion of US$30 billion in addition to the funds it has already received.

08.orig_text: Of the government ownership he stated that he refused ``to let General Motors and Chrysler become wards of the state``, and described the bankruptcy of Chrysler, and the bankruptcy of General Motors that he envisioned as being ``quick, surgical, bankruptcies``.
08.text: Of the government ownership he stated that he refused ``to let General Motors and Chrysler become wards of the state``, and described the bankruptcy of Chrysler, and the bankruptcy of General Motors that he envisioned as being ``quick, surgical, bankruptcies``.

09.orig_text: He pointed to the bankruptcy of Chrysler as an example of what he envision for General Motors, but stated that General Motors was a ``more complex company`` than Chrysler.
09.text: He pointed to the bankruptcy of Chrysler as an example of what he envision for General Motors, but stated that General Motors was a ``more complex company`` than Chrysler.

10.orig_text: Responding to challenges voiced by political opponents, before the speech, that the federal government would actively participate in the affairs of the restructured company, he stated that he had ``no interest`` in running GM, and that the federal government would ``refrain from exercising its rights`` as a corporate shareholder for the most part.
10.text: Responding to challenges voiced by political opponents, before the speech, that the federal government would actively participate in the affairs of the restructured company, he stated that he had ``no interest`` in running GM, and that the federal government would ``refrain from exercising its rights`` as a corporate shareholder for the most part.

11.orig_text: In particular, he stated that the federal government would not exercise its rights as a shareholder to dictate ``what new type of car to make.``
11.text: In particular, he stated that the federal government would not exercise its rights as a shareholder to dictate ``what new type of car to make.``

12.orig_text: He stated that he expected the restructured GM to make ``high quality, safe, and fuel-efficient cars of tomorrow,`` and several times described what he anticipated as ``better`` and ``fuel-efficient`` cars, after a streamlining of GM's brands.
12.text: He stated that he expected the restructured GM to make ``high quality, safe, and fuel-efficient cars of tomorrow,`` and several times described what he anticipated as ``better`` and ``fuel-efficient`` cars, after a streamlining of GM's brands.

13.orig_text: He said to the general public that ``I will not pretend that the hard times are over.``
13.text: He said to the general public that ``I will not pretend that the hard times are over.``

14.orig_text: He described the financial hardship that some -- shareholders, communities based around GM plants, GM dealers, and others -- would undergo as a ``sacrifice for the next generation`` on their parts, so that their children could live in ``an America that still makes things,`` concluding that one day the United States might return to a time when the maxim (a widely-repeated mis-quotation of what Charles Erwin Wilson once testified before the U.S. Senate when nominated for the position of Secretary of Defense) would once more be true that ``what is good for General Motors is good for the United States of America.``

00.orig_text: CEO of GM outlines plan for ``New GM`` after auto company declared bankruptcy
00.text: CEO of GM outlines plan for ``New GM`` after auto company declared bankruptcy

02.orig_text: In a New York press conference at 16:15 UTC, June 1st, Fritz Henderson, the Chief Executive Officer of General Motors, which filed for bankruptcy and Chapter 11 protection from its creditors earlier today, outlined a plan for what he called a ``New GM``.
02.text: In a New York press conference at 16:15 UTC, June 1st, Fritz Henderson, the Chief Executive Officer of General Motors, which filed for bankruptcy and Chapter 11 protection from its creditors earlier today, outlined a plan for what he called a ``New GM``.

03.orig_text: Speaking to the press under safe harbor provisions of U.S. law, Henderson described the events of today as a ``defining moment`` in the history of General Motors.
03.text: Speaking to the press under safe harbor provisions of U.S. law, Henderson described the events of today as a ``defining moment`` in the history of General Motors.

04.orig_text: Speaking to the public he said that ``The GM that let you down is history,`` and described a ``New GM`` that he expected to result from the bankruptcy process.
04.text: Speaking to the public he said that ``The GM that let you down is history,`` and described a ``New GM`` that he expected to result from the bankruptcy process.

05.orig_text: Henderson stated that he envisioned the bankruptcy process would take between 60 and 90 days.
05.text: Henderson stated that he envisioned the bankruptcy process would take between 60 and 90 days.

06.orig_text: He stressed several times his view that the process would be one that is executed quickly, saying that not just a sense of urgency but ``pure unadulterated speed`` was his expectation of the process.
06.text: He stressed several times his view that the process would be one that is executed quickly, saying that not just a sense of urgency but ``pure unadulterated speed`` was his expectation of the process.

07.orig_text: He emphasized that ``GM remains open for business`` during the bankruptcy period, continuing to sell and to support its products, and that day one motions had been filed in the bankruptcy court in order to allow this.
07.text: He emphasized that ``GM remains open for business`` during the bankruptcy period, continuing to sell and to support its products, and that day one motions had been filed in the bankruptcy court in order to allow this.

08.orig_text: Regarding the bankruptcy process he said, ``We will do it right.
08.text: Regarding the bankruptcy process he said, ``We will do it right.

09.orig_text: And we will do it once.``
09.text: And we will do it once.``

10.orig_text: He stated that the plan for General Motors had the support of the United Auto Workers union, the Canadian Auto Workers union, the GM VEBA, and a majority of the unsecured bondholders of GM.
10.text: He stated that the plan for General Motors had the support of the United Auto Workers union, the Canadian Auto Workers union, the GM VEBA, and a majority of the unsecured bondholders of GM.

11.orig_text: He also mentioned that GM had already received $1.5 million in bridge financing from the German government.
11.text: He also mentioned that GM had already received $1.5 million in bridge financing from the German government.

12.orig_text: In response to questions about the possibility of the United States federal government, a majority shareholder in the restructured company, dictating future product development and strategy, such as the sale of more fuel-efficient and green vehicles; he first observed that the federal government had already stated to him that it had ``no real interest in running our business`` and that he expected that still to be his job.
12.text: In response to questions about the possibility of the United States federal government, a majority shareholder in the restructured company, dictating future product development and strategy, such as the sale of more fuel-efficient and green vehicles; he first observed that the federal government had already stated to him that it had ``no real interest in running our business`` and that he expected that still to be his job.

13.orig_text: Of the specific hypothetical scenario where the management of GM wants to make one type of car, because it thinks that it is the right thing for the business, and the U.S. government wants to make another type of car, he stated that ``I don't think it's going to happen.``
13.text: Of the specific hypothetical scenario where the management of GM wants to make one type of car, because it thinks that it is the right thing for the business, and the U.S. government wants to make another type of car, he stated that ``I don't think it's going to happen.``

14.orig_text: Expanding on that point he stated that he expected the ``New GM`` to focus upon ``highly fuel-efficient and green technology``, and that operating both in accordance with U.S. environmental laws and in response to customer demand would naturally result in the New GM producing the types of vehicles that the U.S. government would encourage.
14.text: Expanding on that point he stated that he expected the ``New GM`` to focus upon ``highly fuel-efficient and green technology``, and that operating both in accordance with U.S. environmental laws and in response to customer demand would naturally result in the New GM producing the types of vehicles that the U.S. government would encourage.

15.orig_text: The ``New GM`` he also expected to focus on ``four core brands``, and will size its dealership to match that.
15.text: The ``New GM`` he also expected to focus on ``four core brands``, and will size its dealership to match that.

16.orig_text: He stated that GM would offer a ``deferred termination`` package to dealers, to allow them to cease dealing in GM vehicles in a managed and gradual way.
16.text: He stated that GM would offer a ``deferred termination`` package to dealers, to allow them to cease dealing in GM vehicles in a managed and gradual way.

17.orig_text: He stated that the bankruptcy filings did not cover General Motors' businesses in Latin America, Europe and the Middle East, and Asia and the Pacific.
17.text: He stated that the bankruptcy filings did not cover General Motors' businesses in Latin America, Europe and the Middle East, and Asia and the Pacific.

18.orig_text: Of GM's profitable ventures in China, specifically, he stated that they were ``a critical part of the New GM``.
18.text: Of GM's profitable ventures in China, specifically, he stated that they were ``a critical part of the New GM``.

19.orig_text: In response to questions of whether the New GM would import cars from China to the U.S., he stated the formative company's core principle that ``We build where we sell`` applied in both directions, with GM building in China to sell in China and building in the U.S. to sell in the U.S., stating that this shortened supply chains.
19.text: In response to questions of whether the New GM would import cars from China to the U.S., he stated the formative company's core principle that ``We build where we sell`` applied in both directions, with GM building in China to sell in China and building in the U.S. to sell in the U.S., stating that this shortened supply chains.

20.orig_text: He declined to predict when the New GM would return to profitability, stating that the goal was rather to lower the break-even EBIT point for the company.
20.text: He declined to predict when the New GM would return to profitability, stating that the goal was rather to lower the break-even EBIT point for the company.

21.orig_text: He also declined to speculate upon when the U.S. government would sell its stake in the company, saying that that was a question ``better addressed to the U.S. Treasury``, and merely saying that he expected it to be ``years, not months`` when the U.S. Treasury felt it would give ``the right return for taxpayers.``
21.text: He also declined to speculate upon when the U.S. government would sell its stake in the company, saying that that was a question ``better addressed to the U.S. Treasury``, and merely saying that he expected it to be ``years, not months`` when the U.S. Treasury felt it would give ``the right return for taxpayers.``

00.text: Apple Inc. CEO Steve Jobs on medical leave

02.orig_text: Steve Jobs, the chief executive officer of Apple Inc., announced Monday in an internal memo that he would be on medical leave for an undetermined period of time.
02.text: Steve Jobs, the chief executive officer of Apple Inc., announced Monday in an internal memo that he would be on medical leave for an undetermined period of time.

03.orig_text: The statement caused a sharp decrease of Apple share prices in foreign markets, while US markets were closed in honor of Martin Luther King.
03.text: The statement caused a sharp decrease of Apple share prices in foreign markets, while US markets were closed in honor of Martin Luther King.

04.orig_text: Monday's email announcement marked the third time in the past decade that Jobs, aged 55, has taken medical leave.
04.text: Monday's email announcement marked the third time in the past decade that Jobs, aged 55, has taken medical leave.

05.orig_text: He fought pancreatic cancer in 2004 and took six months off in early 2009, later revealing he had undergone a liver transplant.
05.text: He fought pancreatic cancer in 2004 and took six months off in early 2009, later revealing he had undergone a liver transplant.

06.orig_text: Jobs has not yet mentioned what prompted his decision this time around, but said he will still be the company's CEO.
06.text: Jobs has not yet mentioned what prompted his decision this time around, but said he will still be the company's CEO.

07.orig_text: He left current chief operating officer Timothy D. Cook in charge of day-to-day operations, the same move made in Jobs' last two absences.
07.text: He left current chief operating officer Timothy D. Cook in charge of day-to-day operations, the same move made in Jobs' last two absences.

08.orig_text: While no additional comment has been officially made by Apple, The New York Times reported that someone familiar with the situation said Jobs's health has ``ups and downs`` due to problems with his immune system, problems frequently experienced by those who have had liver transplants.
08.text: While no additional comment has been officially made by Apple, The New York Times reported that someone familiar with the situation said Jobs's health has ``ups and downs`` due to problems with his immune system, problems frequently experienced by those who have had liver transplants.

09.orig_text: The insider, who asked to remain anonymous, said that, over the past few weeks, Jobs' health appeared to be deteriorating and that he was becoming thinner.
09.text: The insider, who asked to remain anonymous, said that, over the past few weeks, Jobs' health appeared to be deteriorating and that he was becoming thinner.

10.orig_text: Lewis W. Teperman, a doctor at New York University, said, ``It's very common for transplant patients to have issues that are not life-threatening.``
10.text: Lewis W. Teperman, a doctor at New York University, said, ``It's very common for transplant patients to have issues that are not life-threatening.``

11.orig_text: On its website, Apple released the text of Jobs's email, which reads: Team, At my request, the board of directors has granted me a medical leave of absence so I can focus on my health.
11.text: On its website, Apple released the text of Jobs's email, which reads: Team, At my request, the board of directors has granted me a medical leave of absence so I can focus on my health.

12.orig_text: I will continue as CEO and be involved in major strategic decisions for the company.
12.text: I will continue as CEO and be involved in major strategic decisions for the company.

13.orig_text: I have asked Tim Cook to be responsible for all of Apple's day to day operations.
13.text: I have asked Tim Cook to be responsible for all of Apple's day to day operations.

14.orig_text: I have great confidence that Tim and the rest of the executive management team will do a terrific job executing the exciting plans we have in place for 2011.
14.text: I have great confidence that Tim and the rest of the executive management team will do a terrific job executing the exciting plans we have in place for 2011.

15.orig_text: I love Apple so much and hope to be back as soon as I can.

16.orig_text: In the meantime, my family and I would deeply appreciate respect for our privacy.
16.text: In the meantime, my family and I would deeply appreciate respect for our privacy.

02.orig_text: Australian Prime Minister John Howard and federal industry minister Ian MacDonald today announced that the federal government would be providing Ford Australia with a AU$52.5 million (US$40.4 million) ``financial assistance package``.
